intro: Acacia aemula subsp. muricata, commonly known as the rough acacia, is a shrub native to southern Africa. It is characterized by its dense, thorned stems and feathery, bipinnate leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers in spikes, which are often followed by flat, pod-like fruits. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, adapting well to poor soils. Its botanical features make it an important component of local ecosystems and a useful plant for erosion control.

It is found in the southwestern region of the state, particularly in the areas around the Geraldton and Esperance regions. This subspecies thrives in sandy soils and is commonly found in coastal and inland areas. It is adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of its native range.
